question_text: Using thermodynamic principles from combustion science and energy systems, explain why high-purity CO2 streams (>95%) from industries like ethanol fermentation and natural gas processing require near-zero minimum work for separation, and contrast this with the higher separation requirements for dilute combustion flue gases (3-15% CO2). Include the role of entropy of mixing and Gibbs free energy in your explanation.
standard_answer: The thermodynamic minimum work for CO2 separation approaches zero for high-purity streams (>95% CO2) because the feed stream composition closely matches the desired product stream composition. When the CO2 concentration in the feed stream is already above 95%, the Gibbs free energy change between feed and product streams becomes minimal, requiring negligible work to achieve the target purity. This occurs because the entropy penalty for isolating CO2 from the gas mixture is negligible when compositions are similar. In contrast, dilute flue gases (3-15% CO2) require substantial separation work due to the large entropy of mixing that must be overcome. The fundamental difference lies in overcoming the natural mixing tendencies - for pure streams, CO2 molecules are already largely concentrated, requiring only dehydration and compression, while dilute streams demand significant energy expenditure to work against the favorable entropy state of mixed gases. This thermodynamic principle explains why capture costs are substantially lower for high-purity industrial streams compared to dilute combustion sources.
